benchmark_config.jira_title: Implement/Test API: DELETE /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/emails/{email} - Delete email from account

covered: Valid deletion scenarios covered: successful deletes (TC01, TC02, TC12, TC13, TC14, TC15, TC17, TC18, TC19) demonstrate correct deletion behavior and performance under typical circumstances.
Validation and error handling: invalid accountId (TC05), invalid email (TC06), and XSS/injection attempt (TC16) are tested to ensure proper input validation.
Non-existent resource handling: non-existent account (TC03), non-existent email (TC04), and account with no emails (TC09) cover 404 responses for missing data.
Authorization and header validation: missing required header (TC07) and invalid/expired token (TC10) cover authentication/authorization failure cases.
Error conditions: system/service unavailability (TC11) is tested with 503 responses.
Edge case coverage: very long email (TC12) and minimal-length email (TC13) test boundary input handling.
Regression tests: uppercase email deletion (TC17) and backward compatibility (TC18) confirm behavior with case sensitivity and legacy clients.
Resilience: transient network failure and recovery (TC19) validate retry behavior leading to successful deletion.
Extra parameters: unsupported/extra query parameter (TC08) checks endpoint robustness against unexpected inputs.
Performance: response time under 500ms (TC14) ensures acceptable deletion latency.
gaps: Rate Limiting: No tests covering rate limiting or throttling for DELETE requests.
Caching Behavior: No tests verifying caching headers (e.g., ETag, Cache-Control) on DELETE responses.
Soft Deletes: No explicit tests verifying whether deletions are soft (tombstones) versus hard deletes.
Idempotency: No explicit idempotency verification (repeated DELETE behavior beyond basic concurrency test).
Pagination: Not applicable for a single-delete operation, but no guidance provided for DELETE-specific pagination scenarios.
recommendations: Add rate-limiting/throttling tests for DELETE to ensure stability under bursty traffic.
Add caching headers validation (ETag, Cache-Control) on DELETE responses if caching is part of the API contract.
Add tests to clarify and verify soft-delete semantics if applicable (e.g., tombstone visibility or recovery).
Add explicit idempotency tests to ensure repeated DELETE calls after a successful deletion behave consistently (expect 204 or 404 as defined by policy).
Document and test any pagination-related expectations for DELETE endpoints if future expansion introduces collection-like DELETE semantics.
